Indicator: Syrian Boys in Camp receiving measles vaccine
comments:
Extension of Provision of TB Detection, Treatment and Prevention Services for Syrian Refugees in Jordan, First Health Screening and Triage and Measles and Polio Immunization for Newly Arrived Syrian Refugees at Rabaal-Sarhan Transit Center

	
Objectives: 

A.To improve access to active TB detection, treatment and prevention services for Syrian refugees  to increase the official TB case notification to the Jordanian Ministry of Health, which in turn is expected to decrease morbidity and mortality due to TB among Syrian refugees and host communities in Jordan.

B. To improve the health status of the population through scaled up immunization services to reduce avoidable morbidity and mortality due to measles, polio, respiratory infections and diarrhea among Syrian refugees and host communities in Jordan.

C. To improve the health status of the population by conducting First Health Screening and Triage to reduce mortality, morbidity and disability through early detection of critical or significant medical conditions and facilitate referrals of life threatening health conditions and conditions requiring non-urgent attention among Syrian refugees upon arrival

Indicator: Syrian Boys in Camp receiving measles vaccine

Project Title: Provision of multidisciplinary services for Refugees and Asylum Seekers in Jordan (Syrian) 

Target group:
1-the vulnerable group of Syrian refugee families registered with the UNHCR, especially those with special needs, women, children, the elderly in the community and in the refugee camps.
2-The Community based organizations CBOs Implementing partners 
Funded By: The UN Refugee Agency UNHCR
Activities: 
1-To provide rehabilitation services and psycho-social support for children with disabilities from mental disabilities and physical- minor to moderate-, learning difficulties and problems of language and speech therapy, and physical therapy sessions. And provide advising sessions for their parents. And provide children in need with hearing aids.

Indicator: Number of rehabilitation sessions conducted by a Physical Therapist and/or Occupational Therapist provided to Syrian boys under 18 in camp

activity: 1. Community health volunteer teams in place
Indicator: # of female community health volunteers trained and supported
comments: Community Health Volunteers under one of two IRD health programs, Health Linkages and National Networks (in Amman, Zarqa, and Irbid) and Health Services for Syrian Refugees (Irbid, Ramtha-Irbid, Mafraq, Zarqa, Salt, Karak, Ma'an), conduct health assessments through home visits, make referrals to local Ministry of Health clinics, and spread awareness about healthcare options, and sometimes distribute NFIs to refugees.

Indicator: Syrian Girls in Camp receiving measles vaccine
comments:
Extension of Provision of TB Detection, Treatment and Prevention Services for Syrian Refugees in Jordan, First Health Screening and Triage and Measles and Polio Immunization for Newly Arrived Syrian Refugees at Rabaal-Sarhan Transit Center

	
Objectives: 

A.To improve access to active TB detection, treatment and prevention services for Syrian refugees  to increase the official TB case notification to the Jordanian Ministry of Health, which in turn is expected to decrease morbidity and mortality due to TB among Syrian refugees and host communities in Jordan.

B. To improve the health status of the population through scaled up immunization services to reduce avoidable morbidity and mortality due to measles, polio, respiratory infections and diarrhea among Syrian refugees and host communities in Jordan.

C. To improve the health status of the population by conducting First Health Screening and Triage to reduce mortality, morbidity and disability through early detection of critical or significant medical conditions and facilitate referrals of life threatening health conditions and conditions requiring non-urgent attention among Syrian refugees upon arrival

activity: 2. Community level referral system in place
Indicator: community level referral system established?
comments: IRD's community health referral system in Za'atri is implemented through the Health Services for Syrian Refugees program and involves a team of resident Community Health Volunteers (CHVs), who conduct health assessments through home visits for refugees in all districts of the camp, provide awareness of healthcare options and health lifestyles (saving time and trouble for both beneficiaries and clinics), and make referrals to local clinics. They follow up with patients throughout their treatment, ensuring that they receive referrals for higher level care when necessary, and conducting exit interviews upon completion of treatment to evaluate services. When NFI donations are available they are also often circulated through CHVs.

They follow up with patients throughout their treatment, ensuring that they receive referrals for higher level care when necessary, and conducting exit interviews upon completion of treatment to evaluate services. When NFI donations are available they are also often circulated through CHVs.

Indicator: Syrian Boys in Camp receiving measles vaccine
comments:
Extension of Provision of TB Detection, Treatment and Prevention Services for Syrian Refugees in Jordan, First Health Screening and Triage and Measles and Polio Immunization for Newly Arrived Syrian Refugees at Rabaal-Sarhan Transit Center

	
Objectives: 

A.To improve access to active TB detection, treatment and prevention services for Syrian refugees  to increase the official TB case notification to the Jordanian Ministry of Health, which in turn is expected to decrease morbidity and mortality due to TB among Syrian refugees and host communities in Jordan.

B. To improve the health status of the population through scaled up immunization services to reduce avoidable morbidity and mortality due to measles, polio, respiratory infections and diarrhea among Syrian refugees and host communities in Jordan.

C. To improve the health status of the population by conducting First Health Screening and Triage to reduce mortality, morbidity and disability through early detection of critical or significant medical conditions and facilitate referrals of life threatening health conditions and conditions requiring non-urgent attention among Syrian refugees upon arrival

Number of rehabilitation sessions conducted by a Physical Therapist and/or Occupational Therapist provided to Syrian girls under 18 in camp
comments:
Project Title: Provision of multidisciplinary services for Refugees and Asylum Seekers in Jordan (Syrian) 

Target group:
1-the vulnerable group of Syrian refugee families registered with the UNHCR, especially those with special needs, women, children, the elderly in the community and in the refugee camps.
2-The Community based organizations CBOs Implementing partners 
Funded By: The UN Refugee Agency UNHCR
Activities: 
1-To provide rehabilitation services and psycho-social support for children with disabilities from mental disabilities and physical- minor to moderate-, learning difficulties and problems of language and speech therapy, and physical therapy sessions. And provide advising sessions for their parents. And provide children in need with hearing aids.

Indicator: Syrian Girls in Camp receiving measles vaccine
comments:
Extension of Provision of TB Detection, Treatment and Prevention Services for Syrian Refugees in Jordan, First Health Screening and Triage and Measles and Polio Immunization for Newly Arrived Syrian Refugees at Rabaal-Sarhan Transit Center

	
Objectives: 

A.To improve access to active TB detection, treatment and prevention services for Syrian refugees  to increase the official TB case notification to the Jordanian Ministry of Health, which in turn is expected to decrease morbidity and mortality due to TB among Syrian refugees and host communities in Jordan.

B. To improve the health status of the population through scaled up immunization services to reduce avoidable morbidity and mortality due to measles, polio, respiratory infections and diarrhea among Syrian refugees and host communities in Jordan.

C. To improve the health status of the population by conducting First Health Screening and Triage to reduce mortality, morbidity and disability through early detection of critical or significant medical conditions and facilitate referrals of life threatening health conditions and conditions requiring non-urgent attention among Syrian refugees upon arrival

activity: 2. Community level referral system in place
Indicator: community level referral system established?
comments: IRD's community health referral system in Za'atri is implemented through the Health Services for Syrian Refugees program and involves a team of resident Community Health Volunteers (CHVs), who conduct health assessments through home visits for refugees in all districts of the camp, provide awareness of healthcare options and health lifestyles (saving time and trouble for both beneficiaries and clinics), and make referrals to local clinics. They follow up with patients throughout their treatment, ensuring that they receive referrals for higher level care when necessary, and conducting exit interviews upon completion of treatment to evaluate services. When NFI donations are available they are also often circulated through CHVs.

Objectives: 

A.To improve access to active TB detection, treatment and prevention services for Syrian refugees  to increase the official TB case notification to the Jordanian Ministry of Health, which in turn is expected to decrease morbidity and mortality due to TB among Syrian refugees and host communities in Jordan.

B. To improve the health status of the population through scaled up immunization services to reduce avoidable morbidity and mortality due to measles, polio, respiratory infections and diarrhea among Syrian refugees and host communities in Jordan.

C. To improve the health status of the population by conducting First Health Screening and Triage to reduce mortality, morbidity and disability through early detection of critical or significant medical conditions and facilitate referrals of life threatening health conditions and conditions requiring non-urgent attention among Syrian refugees upon arrival

Indicator: Number of clinical secondary mental health consultations provided to Syrian men 18 and over in urban setting

activity: 2. Community level referral system in place
Indicator: community level referral system established?
comments: IRD's community health referral systems are implemented through two comparable programs, Health Linkages and National Networks (in Amman, Zarqa, and Irbid) and Health Services for Syrian Refugees (Irbid, Ramtha-Irbid, Mafraq, Zarqa, Salt, Karak, Ma'an). Both involve teams of Community Health Volunteers (CHVs), who conduct health assessments through home visits for refugees and Jordanian residents of host communities, provide increased awareness of healthcare options (saving time and trouble for both beneficiaries and clinics), and make referrals to local Ministry of Health clinics. They follow up with patients throughout their treatment, ensuring that referrals for higher level care are given when necessary, and conducting exit interviews upon completion of treatment to evaluate services. When NFI donations are available they are also often circulated through CHVs.

They follow up with patients throughout their treatment, ensuring that they receive referrals for higher level care when necessary, and conducting exit interviews upon completion of treatment to evaluate services. When NFI donations are available they are also often circulated through CHVs.

comments:
Project Title: Provision of multidisciplinary services for Refugees and Asylum Seekers in Jordan (Syrian) 

Target group:
1-the vulnerable group of Syrian refugee families registered with the UNHCR, especially those with special needs, women, children, the elderly in the community and in the refugee camps.
2-The Community based organizations CBOs Implementing partners 
Funded By: The UN Refugee Agency UNHCR
Activities: 
1-To provide rehabilitation services and psycho-social support for children with disabilities from mental disabilities and physical- minor to moderate-, learning difficulties and problems of language and speech therapy, and physical therapy sessions. And provide advising sessions for their parents. And provide children in need with hearing aids.

Indicator: Syrian Girls in Camp receiving measles vaccine
comments:
Extension of Provision of TB Detection, Treatment and Prevention Services for Syrian Refugees in Jordan, First Health Screening and Triage and Measles and Polio Immunization for Newly Arrived Syrian Refugees at Rabaal-Sarhan Transit Center

	
Objectives: 

A.To improve access to active TB detection, treatment and prevention services for Syrian refugees  to increase the official TB case notification to the Jordanian Ministry of Health, which in turn is expected to decrease morbidity and mortality due to TB among Syrian refugees and host communities in Jordan.

B. To improve the health status of the population through scaled up immunization services to reduce avoidable morbidity and mortality due to measles, polio, respiratory infections and diarrhea among Syrian refugees and host communities in Jordan.

C. To improve the health status of the population by conducting First Health Screening and Triage to reduce mortality, morbidity and disability through early detection of critical or significant medical conditions and facilitate referrals of life threatening health conditions and conditions requiring non-urgent attention among Syrian refugees upon arrival

Indicator: Syrian Girls in Camp receiving measles vaccine

activity: 2. Community level referral system in place
Indicator: community level referral system established?
comments: IRD's community health referral system in Za'atri is implemented through the Health Services for Syrian Refugees program and involves a team of resident Community Health Volunteers (CHVs), who conduct health assessments through home visits for refugees in all districts of the camp, provide awareness of healthcare options and health lifestyles (saving time and trouble for both beneficiaries and clinics), and make referrals to local clinics. They follow up with patients throughout their treatment, ensuring that they receive referrals for higher level care when necessary, and conducting exit interviews upon completion of treatment to evaluate services. When NFI donations are available they are also often circulated through CHVs.

comments:
Project Title: Provision of multidisciplinary services for Refugees and Asylum Seekers in Jordan (Syrian) 

Target group:
1-the vulnerable group of Syrian refugee families registered with the UNHCR, especially those with special needs, women, children, the elderly in the community and in the refugee camps.
2-The Community based organizations CBOs Implementing partners 
Funded By: The UN Refugee Agency UNHCR
Activities: 
1-To provide rehabilitation services and psycho-social support for children with disabilities from mental disabilities and physical- minor to moderate-, learning difficulties and problems of language and speech therapy, and physical therapy sessions. And provide advising sessions for their parents. And provide children in need with hearing aids.

activity: 5. Improve access to mental health service
Indicator: # number of facilities providing mental health services during this month
comments:
Support the integration of mental health in PHC through the delivery of mhGAP supervision and provision of tools to 16 facilities in Amman, Mafraq, Irbid and Ramtha, in coordination with MOH Mental Health Unit. 

Target is 8 additional PHC facilities, bringing total number to 24 facilities (country-wide).

activity: 2. Community level referral system in place
Indicator: community level referral system established?
comments: IRD's community health referral systems are implemented through two comparable programs, Health Linkages and National Networks (in Amman, Zarqa, and Irbid) and Health Services for Syrian Refugees (Irbid, Ramtha-Irbid, Mafraq, Zarqa, Salt, Karak, Ma'an). Both involve teams of Community Health Volunteers (CHVs), who conduct health assessments through home visits for refugees and Jordanian residents of host communities, provide increased awareness of healthcare options (saving time and trouble for both beneficiaries and clinics), and make referrals to local Ministry of Health clinics. They follow up with patients throughout their treatment, ensuring that referrals for higher level care are given when necessary, and conducting exit interviews upon completion of treatment to evaluate services. When NFI donations are available they are also often circulated through CHVs.

Indicator: Number of clinical secondary mental health consultations provided to Syrian girls under 18 in urban setting
comments:
CVT Center located in Al Zarqa Al Jadideh district.

activity: 3. Access to primary and essential secondary
Indicator: # of health facilities equipped
Number of clinical secondary mental health consultations provided to Syrian men 18 and over in urban setting
Syrian Women in Camp - # of GBV survivor who access medical care
comments:
Project title:
a practical emergency prevention and response to GBV and RH among Syrian refugees in Jordan

Objectives:
- To improve awareness and access to quality GBV comprehensive services
- Improve the capacity of heath units to provide clinical management of rape

Target groups:
1. Refugee and host communities (30%) women, girls, men and boys
2. Partner CBOs and health providers dealing with GBV cases

Description of Activities:
- IFH Psychologists provide psychosocial services and counseling to GBV identified cases
-Training of CBO members and health providers on MISP, Clinical Management of Rape, Code of Conduct, Referral systems (SOP), RH & GBV basics
- Provision of basic and comprehensive RH & GBV medical and counseling services

activity: 5. Improve access to mental health service
Indicator: # number of facilities providing mental health services during this month
comments:
Project Title: Provision of multidisciplinary services for Refugees and Asylum Seekers in Jordan (Syrian) 

Target group:
1-the vulnerable group of Syrian refugee families registered with the UNHCR, especially those with special needs, women, children, the elderly in the community and in the refugee camps.
2-The Community based organizations CBOs Implementing partners and
Funded By: The UN Refugee Agency UNHCR
Activities:  (in the camps and the local community)
1-To provide rehabilitation services and psycho-social support for children with disabilities from mental disabilities and physical- minor to moderate-, learning difficulties and problems of language and speech therapy, and physical therapy sessions. And provide advising sessions for their parents. And provide children in need with hearing aids.
2-Screeninng for cases and to be  identified and provide with basic and advanced  psychological sessions awareness-raising sessions.

3- Provide psychological and social services individual and groups sessions for those who are having psychological problems ( like bed wetting for children adjustment problems for adultsetc)

comments:
IRD's Health Linkages and National Networks (HLNN) Program regularly trains Ministry of Health Clinic staff (from clinics which are partnering with the program) on critical health topics. HLNN works in Irbid, Zarqa, and Amman.

Note for March: Due to the high number of activities, IRD does not yet have accurate male/female breakdown of beneficiaries/participants; thus, the total number of participants has been divided equally between males/females for now.

Project Title: Provision of multidisciplinary services for Refugees and Asylum Seekers in Jordan (Syrian)

activity: 2. Community level referral system in place
Indicator: community level referral system established?
comments: IRD's community health referral systems are implemented through two comparable programs, Health Linkages and National Networks (in Amman, Zarqa, and Irbid) and Health Services for Syrian Refugees (Irbid, Ramtha-Irbid, Mafraq, Zarqa, Salt, Karak, Ma'an). Both involve teams of Community Health Volunteers (CHVs), who conduct health assessments through home visits for refugees and Jordanian residents of host communities, provide increased awareness of healthcare options (saving time and trouble for both beneficiaries and clinics), and make referrals to local Ministry of Health clinics. They follow up with patients throughout their treatment, ensuring that referrals for higher level care are given when necessary, and conducting exit interviews upon completion of treatment to evaluate services. When NFI donations are available they are also often circulated through CHVs.

comments: IRD's community health referral systems are implemented through two comparable programs, Health Linkages and National Networks (in Amman, Zarqa, and Irbid) and Health Services for Syrian Refugees (Irbid, Ramtha-Irbid, Mafraq, Zarqa, Salt, Karak, Ma'an). Both involve teams of Community Health Volunteers (CHVs), who conduct health assessments through home visits for refugees and Jordanian residents of host communities, provide increased awareness of healthcare options (saving time and trouble for both beneficiaries and clinics), and make referrals to local Ministry of Health clinics. They follow up with patients throughout their treatment, ensuring that referrals for higher level care are given when necessary, and conducting exit interviews upon completion of treatment to evaluate services. When NFI donations are available they are also often circulated through CHVs.

activity: 2. Community level referral system in place
Indicator: community level referral system established?
comments:
Objective:
Provide quality comprehensive RH services and promote reproductive health rights

Target groups:
Refugee women, men, girls and boys 

Description of the Project:
IFH will provide critical outreach activities targeting Syrian refugees within the host community to disseminate information on the availability and type of services available to Syrians, and increase access to quality RH and GBV services.

Activities include:
- Conduct awareness activities on RH & GBV
- Provision of RH related medical \ counseling services
- Perform specialized home visits
- Distribution of IEC material
- Conduct campaigns on RH & GBV

comments:
CVT Center located in Al Zarqa Al Jadideh district.
Number of newly registered clients per month (number of ongoing clients from previous months who were provided services during the reporting month are not including to avoid that the same clients be counted more than once).
Age group cut-point is 18 years old (girls/boys are below 18 Y/O; women/men are 18 and above).
The category "Men - Other affected Population" is lacking. In January 2014, 2 "men - other affected population" registered with CVT in Zarqa.
(Funding resources: BPRM; USAID; UNVFTV; Others)

comments:
Comments: Project title:
a practical emergency prevention and response to GBV and RH among Syrian refugees in Jordan

Objectives:
- To improve awareness and access to quality GBV comprehensive services
- Improve the capacity of heath units to provide clinical management of rape

Target groups:
1. Refugee women, girls, men and boys

Description of Activities:
- IFH Psychologists provide psychosocial services and counseling to GBV identified cases
- Provision of basic and comprehensive RH & GBV medical and counseling services
